To His Excellency: HQN. ADAM IicMULLE.V, Governor, of Nebraska. - ■ Sir: Nebraska, less than a century and a quarter ago,, was described as "a vast expanse of desert wasteland, fit only for tile habitation of the Indian". Today; slic can rightly claim first rank as a producer of agricultural products from the standpoint of surplus production of all leading staple crops, livestock and livestock nrodncts. The following report of the State anil Federal Division of Agricultural Statistics will support this claim. The year 1927 was one of unusually heavy crop yields, when new records tor state pro - duction of many crops were ma(lc.[ Ai present, Nebraska, though fifteenth state of the Union m size, is seventh m ncr capita wea'th. ;\nd stands first m the acreage nf alfalfa and wild hay, second m production of corn, sugar beets, all hay and popcorn, third m winter wheat and fifth m acreage of oats and all wheat. In livestock, Nebraska has more cattle per capita than any other state, is second m hog production and the number of lambs fed for market, fourth m creamery butter produced, anil fifth m number of horses and mules on farms. The 1927 wheat crop of 7.3.R26.000 bushels was the largest m our history, the corn pro - duction of 291,4^46,000 bushels was. the second largest, and barley set a new state record of 7,577,000 bushcljt." Unusually high July temperatures injured the oat crop severely but the production of C9.513.0ni bushels is above the live year average', mainly because of heavy yields m the early southern section of the state. Sugar beet production was the largest yet recorded m the -state, l,027.o:)0 tons, again placing Nebraska second among the states of the country. Due to low prices the value of crops was not as high as would be expected but the December 1 value of all crops was $373,281,00 an increase of $118,947,1X10 over 1926 anil some $58, 094, )JU0. ab0ve the five year average figure of value. Nebraska livestock interests were severely injured by the very low hog prices and the enforced heavy marketings of 1925 left the farms of parts of the state without a normal number of animals. However, farmers increased lamb feeding operations about CO% over 1926, and feil 9%' more cattle than had been fed the year before, and did so m the face of a feeder shortage which reduced finishing operations m every other state except Kansas. At the close of the year, the range area was m excellent condition, though a cattle shortage existed. Farmers had more hojis on hand at the close of the year. Records showed a net inshipment of approximately 10, 000 head of dairy breeding stock. The value of all Nebraska livestock was $274, 5.15, UUU as compared to $249,577,000 the year previous. An enormous increase m dairy production has taken place m Xrlirn«len m the past half decade, the total value of manufactured products increasing from $18,303,000 m 1922 to $30,716,000 m 1927. New creameries anil cheese factories have been established at an unprecedented rate and the trend toward milking, and the handling of poultry on all farms is a sign of a more diversified and substantial type of business throughout the entire state. The Division of Statistics has continued all its operations of earlier yearsj and is in - creasing its efforts toward publicity for the agriculture of the state, and the education of the farmer m how to use the estimates anil reports of the State and Federal Division of Agricultural Statistics. .The assessor's Census of crop acreages is used as a basis for esti - mates, rural carrier's surveys of the spring and fall pig crops are made, actual railroad records of grain and livestock shipped from Nebraska, and livestock received m Nebraska are utilized m livestock estimating. In addition to. the publication oi the annual report and the regular monthly crop reports of condition and probable yield, some 150 stories are written for the press oi the state and addresses are given to groups throughout Nebraska, explain - ing the use ami value of Agricultural Statistics. The yearly report of the Division is one of the most complete published by any state and is well "recognized. Agricultural College libraries from over 40 slates and some of the In - sular Divisions have asked for complete files for their reference shelves. Business, firms m and out of the state, city libraries, secondary schools, and individual farmers from the en - tire country have asked for information and theif requests have been answered during the year. There lias been a marked increase m the demand for Agricultural Statistics. Respectfully, . 11. J. McLAUGHLIX, Secretary of Agriculture. i 9

Status of Work, Jan. 1, 1028 Progress of the campaign for eradication of bovine tuberculosis from Nebraska farms may be measured by the area over which testing is being done and the number of animals under supervision or by the effect testing has had upon the condition of animals inspected for disease at the terminal markets. Ten of Nebraska's 93 counties were under supervision for tuberculosis eradication on January 1, 1925. These ten counties contained a quarter million cattle and half a million hogs, or 8.9% and 11.4% of the total cattic and hog populations, respectively. No counties, however, had completed the test and been declared tuberculosis free areas at that time. On January I, 1928, 47.8% of all. the hogs and 37.7% of all the cattic in Nebraska were in the 39 counties under state and Federal supervision for disease eradication. Farmers in that area owned 2.176,530 hogs and 1,082,347 cattic. Twenty-five o( these counties were included in the accredited free areas, placing 1,310,072 hogs and 670;972 head of Nebraska's cattic in disease free territory". Farmers in those counties arc entitled to' receive the 10c per hundred premium, over market sales price, paid by nil packers for hogs raised in a tuberculosis free county. 'According to the best available records packers paid Nebraska farmers a total of $118,276.00 in accredited area premiums prior to January 1, 1928. A decrease of two-thirds in the number of cattle showing lesions of tuberculosis at Omaha slaughter houses from 1916 to 1927, and the condemnation o( only one-fourth as many hogs in 1927 as in 1922 in the same abattoirs leaves ho douht as to the efficacy of the program of work. The following table and the detailed information on January slaughter of hogs from Burt county, in eastern Nebraska, ( shows more plainly the effect which area testing has had upon disease appearance among animals at terminal markets. 1916 1922 1927 Per cent of hogs showing lesions :._ - _ — - - 16.6% 12.4%. WHY CROr REPORTS They furnish the best basis for legislation affecting the farm industry. They are of vital importance to the prospective purchaser of farm land. They are very essential to the solution of the present day marketing problems. They enable railroads to make a better distribution of cars for moving farm products. They give producers the same foresight to the future price trends that or - ganized dealers possess. They tend to prevent fluctuation in price. Uncertainty of production promotes fluctuation in price. They are the best basis for the producers' problem of buying or selling farm products tn the best advantage. They Rive a picture of surplus and deficient areas of production thereby promoting an economical interchange of products. They serve as an unbiased check on the numerous private reports. The value of the latter is in direct proportion to their accuracy. They eliminate the ill effects of misleading crop reports that would be circulated for private gain if there were no government reports. They tend to prevent monopoly to a large extent. Frequent and wide publicity of the facts concerning supply and demand prevents any group from monopolizing the market. They aid manufacturers in the economical production and distribution of their products which enables them to sell at a lower price than would prevail if such information was lacking. They show the trends of production of cattle and sheep and the resultant prices which enables the producer to plan his operations in accordance with the demand and to increase his profits materially. They give the farmer information on the planting intentions throughout the country sufficiently in advance of planting to prevent over-planting o£ any crop to an extent that might react adversely on price. They reduce the dealer's risk of ownership which enables him to do busi - ness on a smaller margin of profit, and through the stimulus of competition he pays the producer higher prices than could possibly be obtained if uncertainty of production existed. They give the farmer information on pig crops far enough in advance to prevent over production or under production which will enable him to avoid dis - astrous price fluctuation to a large extent. This is probably of greater econ - omic importance than any other phase of the work. They promote legitimate speculation which helps to maintain maximum price and discourage injurious speculation which arises when the facts on production are lacking or are known by only a few. Publication of the facts is the best way to eliminate the ill effects of excessive speculation. They eliminate some of the uncertainty of the market thereby reducing the dealer's handling risk. The greater the dealer's risk, the larger the margin of profit taken, and the lower the price to the producer. A steady flow of crop reports is essential to the maintenance of maximum farm prices. They benefit all farmers indirectly through not only the elimination of the ill effects of misleading reports but also through the maintenance of maximum price by the indicated price trend which reduces the dealer's handling risk thereby enabling him to buy and sell on smaller margins, and the producer profits by the advanced price. They are the best basis for adjusting supply to demand, which is highly essential if maximum price is to prevail. The greater the frequency and ac - curacy of agricultural forecasts and the greater the knowledge of demand the sooner will price respond to supply and demand. Violent fluctuation in price often arises from uncertainty of supply and demand. 194

HOW ARE FARMERS BENEFITED FROM CROP REPORTS All farmers receive an indirect benefit from government crop and livestock reports. Those who study and use them receive in addition a direct benefit. The indirect benefit comes largely through the counteraction of misleading cron reports, and through the main - tenance of maximum price which cannot prevail permanently when crop reports are lacking. Since the indirect benefits come automatically, this article will deal with the direct benefits which can only be obtained by the study and use of crop and livestock reports. Of all factors affecting farm price, the quantity produced has the greatest influence. While it is impossible to control farm production to an extent that will make supply and demand balance, it is possible to eliminate extremes of production to a considerable extent through adjustment of acreage. _ The planting intention surveys R've the information on acreage in sufficient time to adjust acreage more nearly the normal, or to that which may meet expected future demand. The acreage planted is an important factor in production taken for the country as a whole. While weather conditions may affect production much more than a marked change in acreage may effect it in limited localities, this is not the case for the country as a whole, be - cause the larger the area the less the effect of weather since high production in regions of favorable weather counteract low production in regions of less favorable weather for crops. After a crop is produced the next step is to decide when to sell to the best advantage. In the case of some crops the question is whether to sell for cash or to feed it. The farmer should have the information on production for the country as a whole and in some cases information on world conditions, fnr a -guide as to hnw nnd when to dispose of his crop to the greatest advantage. This is the information that the terminal market dealers use as a guide in the handling of farm commodities. Often the quality of a crop has an important influence on price. A corn crop, for example may be large, but if the quality is low, so much more' be needed for feeding that the quantity may be reduced to an extent that will advance prices. The 1927 corn crop was a splendid example of this. The quality o! the wheat crop may be poor over much of the country and good in other parts which is another factor in marketing which the farmer could I use to his advantage. The control of the meat supply is perhaps .the most important economic factor in farm - ing. The fluctuation in price of meat animals has probably brought more discouragement than anything else with which the farmer has had to contend-. Yet, there is perhaps more opportunity to regulate meat production than crop -production. It requires more study of historic records of meat animal production and prices than in the case of crops, but all of this information is available. ; The control of the pig crop is perhaps somewhat easier than the control of cattle pro - duction due to the shorter period of time necessary to finish for market and that more ad - vance information is available on the pig crop. The pig surveys give the information not only on the present crop but the intentions to breed for the corning crop so that the farmer has all of the information necessary to adjust his production if the future plans appear out of line with prospective future demand. Past records of production and prices are available for study. ■ I The production and price cycles of cattle are naturally of longer duration but they occur i with considerable regularity, and a study of past records in the light of present production I will .enable farmers to adjust production to considerable advantage to themselves. The information on the number of grass cattle for market is of vital importance not only I to the cattle producer but to the cattle feeder as well. Both should know the situation as to } the number available and also the corn and feed situation. The sooner such economic in - ;J formation is available, the more intelligently can marketing and feeding operations be planned. The price of any commodity cannot exceed the price that the consumer will pay. This is the limit under which the dealer or manufacturer of farm commodities must operate. The n handling margin extends from that to the price paid for the raw material, and for this reason he collects all the information available. The more dependable the dealer's information, on [| production and consumption, the less the risk of handling on' the way from the producer to l| the consumer, and the higher the price paid to the producer due to the competition for the I business which forces price upward in direct proportion to the risk of ownership. If all (t producers recognized this absolute fact in marketing and cooperated in furnishing produc- I tion information, they would not be paying so much for the risk of ownership of their commodi- I ties on the way to the consumer as they now are. A continuous flow of information on produc- I tion which gives the facts to all concerned will insure a higher level of prices to producers than |f when the information is limited and unreliable. 195

Prevents ill effects of misleading crop reports 2. Reduces speculation. Dependable information on supply stabilizes Drices -md r,. dneeythe speculauon margin that is necessarily taken when unceJtai"" ol "Spjfy 3. (C) Dealers and Handlers of Agricultural Products: I. Reflects price trends, reduces .peculation which K oes with uncertainty of supply ""rm'pHcM* nccessar > "="■•»■"« '"•"•Sin and enables the payment of maximum (D) Agricultural College Workers: 1. Best basis for crop production programs. (E) State Marketing Bureaus: I. First essential for all marketing programs. (F) Bankers and Financiers: 1. Basis for providing credit lor production, storage and marketing of crops. (Q) Railroads: 1. Enables economical distribution of cars for moving crops and livestock. (H) Insurance Companies: 1. Basis for crop insurance and for placing farm loans. (1) Manufacturers: 1 Guide for determining quantities to be manufactured. 2. Best basis for distribution of manufactured products. (J) Advertising Agencies: 1. Enables the placing of advertising to the best advantage. (X) Meat Packers: 1. Reduces the uncertainty of simply, reflects future price (rend and reduces th< necessary handling margin and enables the payment of maximum price which could nut be given otherwise. (L) Chamber of Commerce: 1. Provides facts for advertising local advantages. (M) Prospective Settlers and Investors: I. Best guide to relative agricultural resources and advantages. (N) Legislators: 1 Basis for much of the constructive farm legislation. (0) Economists and Business Analysts: 1. Essential for analyzing agricultural and business conditions. (P) Business Men: I. \aluable guide for determining whether to expand or contract business operations. (Q) National Government: 1. Basis for most activities of the Department of Agriculture. le" isiatio '" '''' l ' me °' Waf ' and necessar y m enacting much of the (arm (R) General Public Welfare: 1. Nearly all business is interdependent. That is. the prosperity and development oi one business depends greatly on the prosperity and development of all other business. Crop reports furnish an indispensible link between agriculture and other lines of business. Agriculture prospers directly and indirectly through the information on price trends that crop reports indicate and other business prospers ! directly and indirectly through the more economical manufacture, transportation l ot products, which m turn increases the buying power of consumers lor farmJ products as well as manufactured products. 196

I The Bureau of Census collects data on the ginnings of cotton each year. Comparison of ra ii I the total cotton ginned is made with the estimates of the Division of Crop and Livestock ' > I Estimates, in the foregoing table. It will be noted that with few exceptions, the Division's : I estimates run very. closely to the actual ginnings, and that the average error for the past 18 I years is only 2.1% under ■ the actual quantity. Cotton is a difficult crop to estimate and it n ' ; I may be assumed that the estimates of other crops are as close to the actual quantity produced er ,'| as cotton, if not closer. There has been marked deve'opment recently in the methods of esti - ™ ' I mating crops. The old percentage method of estimating has been abandoned and actual sample " e I acreage data that is representative of the whole is gathered in the individual farm surveys " rs i I and the rural carriers' survey. The crop irfeter which is an adaptation of the common speedo - ion I meter is being used, to measure acreage and has proven to be very dependable for all major rm 1 crops and for minor crops that are grown in concentrated areas. Methods of checking in- I completeness in assessor s acreage reports have made that source one of the best in many 1 states. A large quantity of basic data on livestock is now available and the methods ot ! I estimating livestock have been developed greatly during the past few years. The indications I I from the pig surveys have checked very closely with market receipts. 197
